title: 111_hr5913
content:
The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General can provide grants to law enforcement agencies for implementing an anonymous tip program via cell phone text messaging. The funds can be used for developing, expanding, and promoting the program, with the federal share not exceeding 75 percent of the total cost. The program costs, including reward money, and promotion through various marketing methods are covered by the grant. The Federal share of the grant cannot exceed 75 percent of the program cost. Grant funds must supplement, not replace, non-Federal funds for program activities. The program requirements include the Federal share of the grant not exceeding 75 percent of the program cost and grant funds supplementing non-Federal funds for program activities. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with certain requirements. These include administering the program, stripping incoming text messages of identifying information, ensuring the text tip is untraceable, not replacing existing hotlines, training personnel to respond to text tips, making the program compatible with mobile phone providers, and including unidentifiable features. The law enforcement agency must train personnel to respond to text tips, make the program compatible with mobile phone providers, include an unidentifiable code for follow-up information, allow for tip abortion, and not impose additional fees on tipsters' mobile phones. The law enforcement agency must promote the texting program to encourage citizens, especially youth, to participate. No additional fees can be imposed on tipsters' mobile phones. Only standard messaging rates apply. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS. To request a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General containing required information. Each application must certify that the program meets Act requirements. SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS. SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS. Recipients of grants must submit yearly reports on activities' effectiveness to the Attorney General. The Attorney General will then report to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "texting tip program" allows citizens to anonymously text tips to law enforcement agencies to aid in criminal justice by stripping texts of identifying information. "Texting" refers to sending written messages from a mobile phone. 

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2016 for the Attorney General to carry out this Act.
